Faculty of Metallurgy and Energy Engineering Kunming University of Science and Technology Kunming Yunnan 650093 China In2O3-based catalysts are considered to be promising catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol, while ZrO2 exhibits a significant improvement of the catalytic activity of In2O3 catalysts. In this work, Inx-Zry mixed oxides catalysts were prepared by a hydrothermal method and tested for methanol synthesis from CO2 hydrogenation at 260–320 °C and 2–5 Mpa. The results showed that all Inx-Zry mixed oxides catalysts show superior catalytic performances than pure In2O3 due to the contribution of oxygen vacancies and the activation of CO2 by zirconia. Further investigation showed that the catalytic performance of Inx-Zry mixed oxide with the coexistence of In-VO-In and In-VO-Zr sites is better than that of In4Zr6Ox-CP solid solution which only possesses single In-VO-Zr sites, due to the higher oxygen vacancy content and stronger electronic interactions between In and Zr species. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords CO2 hydrogenation Methanol synthesis Zirconia Indium oxide catalyst Data availability The data that has been used is confidential. 1 Introduction Carbon dioxide (CO2) is the main greenhouse gas whose excessive emissions have unquantifiable impacts on the environment and ecology, and threaten the living system on which human beings depend [1–3]. As a result, CO2 capture, utilization, and storage (CCUS) technologies have been proposed as a means of reducing the greenhouse impact [4]. Serving as both chemical feedstock and fuel, methanol (CH3OH) has a broad developing prospect. Now, methanol synthesis from CO2 hydrogenation is one of the most attractive and promising ways to convert CO2 into high-value-added products for the utilization of CO2 (Eq. (1)) [5]. However, the development of efficient catalytic systems is still a challenge of this research, since CO2 is difficult to be activated, and the traditional Cu-based catalysts also show low methanol selectivity and insufficient stability resulting from reverse water-gas shift (RWGS) reaction (Eq. (2)). In the last decade, many researchers have made efforts to develop improved catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation, and indium oxide (In2O3)-based catalysts are one of them [6]. (1) C O 2 + 3 H 2 → C H 3 O H + H 2 O Δ H = − 49.01 k J m o l − 1 (2) C O 2 + H 2 → C O + H 2 O Δ H = + 41.17 k J m o l − 1 In2O3 is an important metal oxide that is widely used in gas-sensitive and catalytic applications [7]. Prior to its application in the hydrogenation of CO2 to methanol, In2O3 was studied for methanol steam reforming (MSR) [8]. Having been proven experimentally and theoretically, In2O3-based catalysts are considered to be promising catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation with high catalytic activity [9–13]. A DFT calculation of CO2 adsorption and hydrogenation on In2O3(110) surface indicated that RWGS reaction can be inhibited by In2O3, which can lead to a higher selectivity [12]. The oxygen vacancy (Ov) generated on the surface of In2O3, which can help activation and hydrogenation of CO2, dissociation of H2, and stabilize the key intermediates, plays as an active site in CO2 hydrogenation, while the formation of In° can also result in catalyst deactivation [14,15]. DFT study also has shown that the pathway forming *HCOO species is the most favorable route for CO2 hydrogenation on In2O3(110), and the intermediate species formate (*HCOO) is important for the formation of methanol on In2O3 surface [12]. Previous studies have already indicated that bulk In2O3 exhibit superior catalytic activity for CO2 hydrogenation [10,16,17]. At 330 °C and 4 Mpa, CO2 conversion reaches 7.13%, with 2.82% of methanol yield. Furthermore, it has been proved that In2O3 with different crystal structures is endowed with different catalytic properties [11]. Qin and Lin studied by DFT calculation and reported that owing to its beneficial formation of oxygen vacancies and hydride adsorbate, h-In2O3(104) surface is superior to c-In2O3(111), c-In2O3 (110), and h-In2O3 (012), leading to the best catalytic performance [18]. In the RWGS reaction, Wang et al. investigated the performance of In2O3 with various crystal phases and found that c-In2O3 has a greater RWGS rate than the hexagonal phase at temperatures below 350 °C, due to the enhanced adsorption of dissociated H2, easily formed oxygen vacancies, and improved capacity to adsorb and activate CO2 [19] . Although the In2O3 catalyst has a high methanol selectivity, further improvement of CO2 conversion is still needed. In order to further enhance the catalytic performance of In2O3 catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation, the modification of In2O3 such as by adding additives [20,21], incorporating of supports [22–24], and loading metals [25–29] has been studied. Among them, ZrO2 exhibits a significant improvement of the catalytic activity of In2O3 catalysts. Martin et al. found that ZrO2-supported In2O3 showed superior stability over 1000 h with high selectivity and increased oxygen vacancy, attributed to the electronically interacting of ZrO2 [10]. Yang et al. investigated supported In2O3 with different crystallization phases of ZrO2 and found that In2O3/m-ZrO2 exhibits higher activity and selectivity than In2O3/t-ZrO2 [23]. In situ Raman spectra showed that the In-O-In structure is highly dispersed over In2O3/m-ZrO2, and the electronic interaction between In2O3 and m-ZrO2 was confirmed by XPS, which facilitates the dissociation of H2 and hydrogenation of intermediates. Tsoukalou et al. reported that the oxidation state of In in In2O3/m-ZrO2 is between +3 and +2, while below +2 in In2O3/t-ZrO2, and the formation of the active site m-ZrO2:In solid solution favors the generation of oxygen vacancies and prevents the deactivation of the catalyst [24,30]. Previous studies have focused more on ZrO2-supported In2O3 catalysts, mainly on the interaction between the ZrO2 carrier and In2O3. The role of ZrO2 in supported systems, such as creating more oxygen vacancies, facilitating the dissociation of H2, and improving the stability of the catalyst, has been studied in detail. However, Frei et al. synthesized In2O3-ZrO2 by co-precipitation method and found that the In2O3-ZrO2 systems showed inferior performances compared to the ZrO2-supported indium oxide catalysts [31]. Thus, it seems necessary to further investigate non-loaded In2O3-ZrO2 catalysts and probe the structure and performance relationships of complex oxide catalysts. Herein, a series of Inx-Zry mixed oxides catalysts with different In/Zr molar ratios were prepared by a hydrothermal method. To investigate the effect of ZrO2 on methanol synthesis from CO2 hydrogenation over In2O3 catalyst, the catalytic properties, including CO2 conversion (XCO2), product selectivity (Si), and methanol space-time yield (STYMeOH) were evaluated, and the transmission electron microscopy (TEM), X-ray diffraction (XRD), Raman spectra, N2 adsorption-desorption, inductively coupled plasma (ICP), H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR), CO2 temperature-programmed desorption (CO2-TPD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and in situ Diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (in situ DRIFTS) were used to characterize the properties of the catalysts. In addition, the In4Zr6Ox-CP (solid solution structure) and In4-Zr6-PM (physical mixing of In2O3 and ZrO2) were synthesized for comparative study to clarify the structure-activity relationship. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts preparation A series of Inx-Zry mixed oxides catalysts were synthesized by a hydrothermal method with In/Zr molar ratio of 2/8, 4/6, 6/4, and 8/2, denoted as In2-Zr8, In4-Zr6, In6-Zr4, and In8-Zr2, respectively. Typically, appropriate amounts of In(NO3)3·xH2O (Alfa Aesar, 99.99%, metals basis) and Zr(NO3)4·5H2O (Alfa Aesar, 99.99%, metals basis) were dissolved in deionized water (600 mL), followed by the addition of NH4OH (Sigma-Aldrich, 25 wt.% in H2O) until the pH reached 9. After 30 min of vigorous stirring, the slurry was transformed into a Teflon-lined hydrothermal synthesis autoclave, lasting for 24 h under 180 °C. When the autoclave cooled down to room temperature, the solid in it was able to be separated by a high-speed centrifuge first, and then washed with deionized water as well as ethanol one after another 3 times. At last, the Inx-Zry mixed oxides samples were available after being dried under 80 °C for 12 h and calcined in static air under 500 °C (heating rate 1 °C·min−1) for 2 h. Similarly, c-In2O3 and t-ZrO2 were also prepared in this way. In4Zr6Ox-CP catalysts were prepared by a co-precipitation method. In a typical preparation case, appropriate amounts of In(NO3)3·xH2O (Alfa Aesar, 99.99%, metals basis) and Zr(NO3)4·5H2O (Alfa Aesar, 99.99%, metals basis) were dissolved in deionized water (500 mL), followed by the addition of NH4OH (Sigma-Aldrich, 25 wt.% in H2O) until the pH reached 9. After stirring for 1 h, the resulting slurry was aged for 2 h. Thereafter, the solid was separated by filtration first and then washed with deionized water and ethanol. At last, the In4Zr6Ox-CP sample was available after being dried under 80 °C for 12 h and calcined in static air under 500 °C for 2 h. In this work, the molar ratio of In/Zr is 4:6. And In4-Zr6-PM catalyst was prepared by physical mixing of c-In2O3 and t-ZrO2, and the molar ratio of In/Zr is 4:6. 2.2 Catalyst characterization Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) was performed on a Rigatku MiniFlex600 X-ray diffractometer with an accelerated voltage of 40 kV, a detector current of 100 mA, and Cu Ka radiation. The intensity data were collected in the range of 2θ= 5–90 ° The diffraction patterns were compared to the data in the Joint Committee on Powder Standards (JCPDS) database to identify the crystallite phase of the catalysts. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM), High-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) images, and selected area electron diffraction (SAED) were conducted with a Talos F200S field emission electron microscope. Prior to testing, the samples were dispersed in ethanol and then sonicated using ultrasound irradiation. Nitrogen adsorption-desorption was carried out using a Quantachrome ASiQwin. Prior to the measurement, the sample was degassed at 300 °C for 6 h under vacuum. The total surface area was determined using the Brunauer-Emmet-Teller (BET) method, while the pore volume and pore size distribution were calculated using the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. The metallic contents of In and Zr in the samples were characterized by an Inductively Coupled Plasma Optical Emission Spectrometer (ICP-OES) on the Agilent 5110. The Raman spectra measurements were performed using a Thermo Scientific DXR 3 Raman microscope. Temperature-programmed reduction with hydrogen (H2-TPR) was measured using a Quantachrome Chem BET Pulsar & TPR/TPD chemisorption instrument. After sample (30 mg) preprocessing at 150 °C in a flow of pure He for 30 min, the H2-TPR analysis program proceeded at 50–900 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C·min−1 in 10 vol% H2/Ar (75 mL·min−1). CO2 temperature-programmed desorption (CO2-TPD) experiment was also carried out with Quantachrome Chem BET Pulsar & TPR/TPD chemisorption instrument. First, the catalyst (100 mg) was pretreated at 300 °C for 60 min with He and then cooled to 30 °C. After that, the catalyst was saturated in flowing CO2 for 60 min and followed by a He flow for 30 min. The CO2-TPD analysis program was carried out at 50–800 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C·min−1 in a flow of He. The peak area of the CO2-TPD result was quantitatively calibrated by CO2 titration. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurement of all catalysts was performed using a Thermo Scientific K-Alpha spectrometer equipped with an Al Kα radiation (hν = 1486.6 eV). The binding energies of selected elements were calibrated by using the C 1 s peak at 284.8 eV as a reference. In situ Diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (in situ DRIFTS) experiments were performed on a Bruker VERTEX 70 spectrometer, equipped with a mercury-cadmium-telluride (MCT) detector cooled by liquid N2. The spectra were recorded from 4000 to 600 cm−1 with a resolution of 4 cm−1. The catalyst sample was placed in the high-pressure reaction chamber and pretreated in Ar for 30 min at 300 °C firstly. In situ DRIFTS experiments were performed at 3 Mpa under a flow of mixed gas (H2/CO2 ratio = 3), and all DRIFTS spectra were collected at a steady state. 2.3 Catalytic test The catalytic test was carried out in a stainless steel continuous-flow fixed-bed reactor with a length of 320 mm and a diameter of 6 mm. The bed was loaded with 0.5 g of the sample (20–40 mesh) and 1.5 g of quartz particles (20–40 mesh). Prior to testing, the pressure of the reactor was increased to 3.0 MPa with N2 flow, and the temperature was increased to 300 °C in 30 min. After 1 h, the gas flow was switched to the hybrid gas. The catalytic evaluation of CO2 hydrogenation to methanol was tested under the following conditions: gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) =12,000 h − 1 , H2/CO2 ratio = 3. All catalytic data were obtained when the reaction had reached a steady state. The reaction products were analyzed by an online gas chromatograph (GC, Agilent 6890 N) equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID, for analysis of CH3OCH3, CH4, and CH3OH) and a thermal conductivity detector (TCD, for analysis of H2, CO2, N2, and CO). CO2 conversion (XCO2), product selectivity (Si, i= CH3OCH3, CH4, CO, and CH3OH), methanol yield (YMeOH), and methanol space-time yield (STYMeOH) were calculated as follows. X C O 2 ( % ) = n in ( C O 2 ) − n out ( C O 2 ) n in ( C O 2 ) × 100 Where nin(CO2) and nout(CO2) represent mol of CO2 at the inlet and outlet, respectively. S i ( % ) = n out i n in ( C O 2 ) + n out ( C O 2 ) × 100 % Where nout(MeOH) denotes mol of methanol at the outlet. Y M e O H ( % ) = X C O 2 ( % ) × S M e O H ( % ) S T Y M e O H ( m m o l · h − 1 · g c a t − 1 ) = Y ( M e O H ) × μ ( C O 2 ) W c a t × V m Where µ(CO2) is the CO2 volumetric flow ( L · h − 1 ) at the entrance of reactor, and V m is 22.4 mol · L − 1 , and Wcat is the weight of the used catalyst sample. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 The effect of zirconia on In2O3 catalysts in CO2 hydrogenation to methanol 3.1.1 Catalytic properties of Inx-Zry mixed oxides catalysts The catalytic evaluation of In2O3 and Inx-Zry mixed oxides catalysts was carried out under the conditions of 300 °C and 3 Mpa. Table 1 shows the profiles of the CO2 conversion, product selectivity, methanol yield, and methanol space-time yield in this test. For all samples, the carbon-containing products of CO2 hydrogenation are CH3OCH3, CH4, CO, and CH3OH under these corresponding conditions. All Inx-Zry mixed oxides catalysts show superior catalytic performances than In2O3. The methanol space-time yield increases firstly and then decreases with the amount of ZrO2, the highest methanol STY is observed over In4-Zr6 catalysts, which is almost 1.5 times than that of In2O3, demonstrating that the catalytic activity can be improved by the adding appropriate amount of ZrO2. Noteworthy, the In4Zr6Ox-CP and In4-Zr6-PM sample, prepared by the co-precipitation method and physical mixing, did not exhibit such remarkable catalytic activity, even worse than that of pure In2O3. The performance differences between the two kinds of catalysts need to be explored and which may be the key to understanding the interaction of the complex oxides. To investigate the effect of reaction temperature on the catalytic performance of Inx-Zry mixed oxides catalysts, the catalyst evaluation of the In4-Zr6 sample under the temperature of 260, 280, and 320 °C was carried out. Fig. 1 a illustrates the curves of CO2 conversion, methanol selectivity, and methanol space-time yield with different temperatures. As displayed, CO2 conversion increases with the increasing reaction temperature in the test temperature range, especially from 300 to 320 °C. This indicates that high temperature is favorable for the activation of CO2. Meanwhile, the methanol selectivity decreases with the increase in temperature, due to the effect of the competitive RWGS reaction. Particularly, the methanol selectivity drops rapidly in the high-temperature range of 280–320 °C, indicating that the RWGS reaction is thermodynamically favored with high temperature. Eventually, the methanol STY increases with increasing reaction temperature, reaching a maximum of 12.95 m m o l · h − 1 · g c a t − 1 . The effect of reaction pressure on the catalytic performance of Inx-Zry mixed oxides was also evaluated. Fig. 1b shows the curves of CO2 conversion, methanol selectivity, and methanol space-time yield at various pressures. Similar to the trend of reaction temperature, CO2 conversion increases with increasing reaction pressure, especially from 4 to 5 Mpa. For methanol selectivity, it decreases slightly with increasing pressure. Overall, the high pressure favors the CO2 hydrogenation, with the highest STY of methanol at 5 MPa reaching 11.45 m m o l · h − 1 · g c a t − 1 . The stability test (time on stream of 50 h) of the catalysts was performed at 300 °C and 3 MPa with the GHSV of 12,000 h−1 (Fig. 1c). At the initial stage of the long-term reaction, the catalytic performance gradually increased and reached a steady state, and then slightly decreased as the reaction proceeded, which demonstrated the good stability of the catalyst. And a comparison of catalyst performance between In4-Zr6 and those reported in the literature is shown in Table 2 . 3.1.2 Textural and structural properties of Inx-Zry mixed oxides catalysts The element content of all samples was tested by ICP-OES, and the results are listed in Table 3 . To explore the crystal properties of catalysts, the XRD was employed and the XRD patterns of Inx-Zry mixed oxides with different In/Zr molar ratios are presented in Fig. 2a . For In8-Zr2 and In6-Zr4, the detected diffraction peaks are more similar to c-In2O3 (JCPDs 06–0416). The characteristic peak is shifted to a high angle, which may be due to the formation of a solid solution, and the solid solubility could not be confirmed due to the similar lattice parameters of c-In2O3 and t-ZrO2. The phase separation of c-In2O3 and t-ZrO2 over In4-Zr6 is clearly observed at 2θ=30–32 ∘ , suggesting the formation of a mixed oxide phase. In detail, the peaks at ca. 2θ=30.3 ∘ and ca. 31.2 ∘ correspond to the (101) plane of t-ZrO2 (JCPDs 88–1007) and c-In2O3 (222), respectively. Fig. S1 shows the XRD pattern of the used catalyst, and there is little difference between the fresh-prepared catalyst and the used one, which indicates the stability of these Inx-Zry mixed oxides catalysts. The In2-Zr8 sample exhibits the diffraction peaks of t-ZrO2, which can be confirmed by the absence of the diffraction peak at ca. 2θ=21.4 ∘ (assigned to the plane facets (211) of In2O3) in particular [34]. The presence of In2O3 causes ZrO2 to grow toward the tetragonal phase, in which In3+ is dissolved in the ZrO2 lattice [31]. Raman spectra of Inx-Zry mixed oxides are shown in Fig. 2b. The peaks at 132, 308, 367, 492, and 629 cm−1 are characteristic peaks of c-In2O3, and the peaks at 151, 271 and 641 cm−1 are ascribed to t-ZrO2. With the addition of ZrO2, the Raman peak intensity of In2O3 gradually decreased, while the characteristic peak of ZrO2 increased, which is in good agreement with the results of XRD. The morphologies and microstructures of Inx-Zry mixed oxides catalysts were examined by TEM and HRTEM. Fig. 3 shows the HRTEM and STEM-HAADF images of the catalysts. In general, the morphology of samples In8-Zr2 and In6-Zr4 is similar, with the presence of flaky In2O3 and spherical ZrO2 nanoparticles, while samples In4-Zr6 and In2-Zr8 catalyst clearly show a completely distinct morphology. Due to the addition of ZrO2, the change in the morphology of In2O3 can be clearly observed, from flaky oxide particles to spherical nanoparticles, accompanied by a decrease in grain size. For In8-Zr2 mixed oxides catalysts in Fig. 3a, the obvious aggregation of In2O3 can be observed. The lattice distances of 0.410 and 0.292 nm belong to In2O3 (211) and (222) planes, respectively, and the lattice distances of 0.181 nm assign to the ZrO2 (200) plane, indicating the presence of separated-ZrO2 or In-Zr solid solution. The energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) elemental maps of the corresponding region (Fig. 3g) can further indicate the existence of the In2O3-rich region. In Fig. 3d, the lattice distance of 0.291, 0.292 and 0.410 nm are attributed to In2O3 (222) and (211), respectively, and the lattice distance of 0.295 nm belongs to the ZrO2 (101) plane. As illustrated in Fig. 3e, unlike In8-Zr2 and In6-Zr4 samples, the In4-Zr6 mixed oxides sample exhibits a more even size and shape. The existence of ZrO2 and In2O3 is in good agreement with the XRD pattern of In4-Zr6 mixed oxides, and the EDX elemental maps also show that In and Zr species are evenly distributed. As displayed in Fig. 3f, similar to In4-Zr6, the In2-Zr8 solid solution sample is present in the form of nanoparticles. In the case of In4-Zr6 mixed oxides catalysts, a decrease in the crystallite size of In2O3 can be clearly observed with the change in the shape, and the average grain sizes of In4-Zr6 and In2-Zr8 catalyst are 8.45 nm and 10.74 nm, respectively. The N2 adsorption-desorption was carried out to determine the BET surface area and pore size distributions of the Inx-Zry mixed oxides, and the textural properties are summarized in Table 3. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore diameter distribution profiles of these catalysts are illustrated in Fig. 4 . According to the IUPAC nomenclature, all samples exhibit type IV adsorption isotherms with hysteresis loops, suggesting the existence of mesoporous in the structure of these samples. As shown in Table 3, the BET surface area of In2O3 is 29.81 m2/g, which may be influenced by the calcination temperature and preparation method [35]. The BET surface area of the Inx-Zry mixed oxides catalyst ranges from 50.84 to 81.49 m2/g, which is significantly higher than that of In2O3. It can be observed that the BET surface area shows an increasing trend with the addition of ZrO2, and this result can further confirm the conclusion of XRD and TEM that the introduction of ZrO2 may affect the structural properties of the Inx-Zry mixed oxides. The enhanced structural properties including the crystallite size and BET surface area facilitate the adsorption and hydrogenation of CO2 and bring about the better catalytic performance of Inx-Zry mixed oxides. 3.1.3 Surface properties of Inx-Zry mixed oxides catalysts The reducibility of Inx-Zry mixed oxides catalysts was studied by the H2-TPR, and the H2-TPR profiles for all catalysts are displayed in Fig. 5a . For all samples, there is only one broad reduction peak starting at ca. 200 °C. It is reported that the main reduction of In2O3 at high temperature is assigned to the reduction of bulk In2O3 into metallic indium, while the peak below 400 °C can be ascribed to the partial reduction of indium species dispersed on the surface, accompanied by the formation of surface oxygen vacancies, and pure ZrO2 cannot be reduced under 800 °C [11,19,36]. With the incorporation of ZrO2, the bulk reduction temperature shifts down clearly, and the decrease of the peak area can be observed at the same time. Distinctly, the catalyst In2-Zr8 has a higher bulk reduction temperature than In4-Zr6 with a significantly reduced peak area, which may be caused by the doping of In3+into the ZrO2 lattice. The formation of the In-Zr solid solution makes the indium species more difficult to be reduced. The surface basicity and CO2 adsorption capacity of Inx-Zry mixed oxides catalysts were investigated by CO2-TPD experiments, and the CO2-TPD profiles for all catalysts are displayed in Fig. 5b. The desorption peaks below 250 °C are attributed to the physically adsorbed CO2 and the higher temperature peaks at 250–500 °C belong to chemisorbed CO2 due to the heat-induced oxygen vacancies on the surface of all samples [11,37]. In the temperature range of this test, it can be divided into two basic adsorption sites, medium basic sites for 250–500 °C and weak basic sites below 250 °C. It can be observed that the peak area increases with the incorporation of ZrO2, which is attributed to the presence of Lewis basic sites on ZrO2, and more basic sites enhance the CO2 adsorption and facilitate the activation of CO2 [38]. Meanwhile, we also calculated the amount of adsorbed CO2, and the results are listed in Table 4 . The order of the total amount of adsorbed CO2 is as follows: In4-Zr6 (2.26 m m o l · g − 1 ) > In2-Zr8 (1.84 m m o l · g − 1 ) >In6-Zr4 (1.61 m m o l · g − 1 ) > In8-Zr2 (1.19 m m o l · g − 1 ) > In2O3 (0.33 m m o l · g − 1 ). The CO2-TPD profiles show that the In4-Zr6 mixed oxides catalysts have more basic sites, resulting in stronger CO2 adsorption capacity and better catalytic activity. XPS spectrum was employed to reveal the surface composition and structure of Inx-Zry mixed oxides catalysts. Fig. 6a displays the spectra of In 3d core level. The peaks appearing at 444.2 and 451.8 eV, assigned to the In 3d5/2 and 3d3/2, respectively, which confirm the oxidation state of In3+. The binding energy of In 3d shifted to higher binding energies slightly with the different molar ratios of In/Zr. The XPS spectra of Zr 3d in Inx-Zry mixed oxides catalysts are shown in Fig. 6b, and there are two peaks, the 3d5/2 at 181–182 eV and 3d3/2 at 184.3–184 eV, respectively, and the binding energy of both peaks are lower than that of pure ZrO2 (182.5 eV and 184.5 eV). It also can be clearly observed that the peaks shift to lower binding energy with the variation of In/Zr molar ratio, suggesting the strong electronic interaction between In and Zr species [23,39]. However, the shift of Zr peaks is larger than that of In peaks, which may be caused by the adsorption of CO2 or H2O. The O 1 s peaks can be deconvoluted into two peaks (Fig. 6c). The major peak at ca.529 eV corresponds to the lattice oxygen (In-O-In, O l a t t i c e ) in In2O3, while the shoulder peak at ca. 531 eV can be attributed to surface oxygen vacancy ( O d e f e c t ) [34,39,40]. In addition, the oxygen vacancies concentration can be calculated by the area ratio of O d e f e c t / ( O l a t t i c e + O d e f e c t ) . The deconvolution and calculation results are listed in Table 5 . The oxygen vacancies concentration is increased to 30.0 %, and then decreased slightly with the increasing of Zr, In4-Zr6 possesses the highest oxygen vacancies concentration among all the catalysts. 3.1.4 Investigation of intermediate in CO2 hydrogenation To investigate the intermediate during the CO2 hydrogenation on In4-Zr6 mixed oxides, the in-situ DRIFTS experiments were carried out under the conditions of 3 Mpa, and the spectra are shown in Fig. 7 . Assignments of the major surface species are summarized in Table 6 . Under the atmosphere of H2 and CO2, CO3* (carbonate), HCOO* (formate) and CH3O* (methoxy) species were observed over In4-Zr6 mixed oxides. In detail, the peaks at 1300 and 1504 cm−1 are assigned to the CO3* and the peaks at 1394 and 1560 cm−1 are attributed to the HCOO* species [41–45]. And the bands centered at 1139, 2821 and 2928 cm−1 are assigned to the CH3O* [46]. In addition, the peaks at 1030, 1055, 2945, 2983, 3012, 2106, and 2176 cm−1 are attributed to methanol, methane, and CO, respectively [47–49]. The peaks of methanol were detected when the temperature reached 220 °C, which demonstrated the good catalytic performance of the In4-Zr6 mixed oxides catalyst at low temperatures. Due to the effect of the RWGS reaction, the signal of CO increased with the increasing temperature, which is consistent with the catalyst evaluation results. The results of in situ DRIFTS showed that formate and methoxy are key intermediates of this catalyst in the CO2 hydrogenation process. As reported in the literature, methanol synthesis over In2O3/ZrO2 follows the formate pathway [23,32]. Based on these two key intermediates we explored in CO2 hydrogenation over In4-Zr6 mixed oxides, we hypothesize that the CO2 hydrogenation reaction over these In-Zr mixed oxides catalyst may also follow this route, which means that the formate species is hydrogenated from the carbonate and subsequently hydrogenated to produce the methoxy species, and then methanol is obtained by hydrogenation of methoxy. 3.2 The structure-activity relationship Based on the above results, the addition of zirconium brought a significant improvement in catalytic performance. We found that the addition of zirconium significantly reduced the grain size of In2O3 in Inx-Zry mixed oxides and increased the BET surface area of the catalyst, in addition to significantly enhancing the basic sites. With the increase of zirconium, bulk indium species reduced gradually, and a smaller well-dispersed indium species appeared. Among all the catalysts, the In4-Zr6 catalyst exhibits the lowest reduction temperature, the highest CO2 adsorption capacity, and oxygen defect concentration, which enhance the catalytic performance. In addition, it is worth noting that the STY of In4-Zr6 mixed oxides catalysts is nearly twice as much as that of In4Zr6Ox-CP, while In4-Zr6-PM even exhibited poor catalytic performance, indicating that there are some differences between these samples that led to the difference in their catalytic performance. To investigate these differences, further experiments were carried out. As shown in Fig. 8 , the XRD pattern of In4Zr6Ox-CP exhibits the diffraction peaks of t-ZrO2, and the diffraction peaks of c-In2O3 are not detected. Moreover, the diffraction peak of In4Zr6Ox-CP shifts to a higher angle, indicating the doping of In3+into the ZrO2 lattice by the formation of solid solution. In addition, the XRD pattern of In4-Zr6-PM exhibits the diffraction peaks of both t-ZrO2 and c-In2O3, and it is noteworthy that the diffraction peaks of this sample are only a simple superposition of diffraction peaks of t-ZrO2 and c-In2O3. Further HRTEM images and corresponding SAED pattern of In4Zr6Ox-CP are shown in Fig. 9 . It can be seen that uniform nanoparticles with a lattice distance of 0.295 nm assigns to the t-ZrO2 (101) plane, and the diffraction circles in SAED pattern are attributed to (002), (200), (103) and (101) plane of t-ZrO2, respectively. The EDX elemental maps (Fig. 9d) also show that In and Zr species are evenly distributed. However, both c-In2O3 and t-ZrO2 are detected for In4-Zr6 sample. The phase difference between the two catalysts may be the key to various catalytic performance. The results of ICP-OES showed that In4Zr6Ox-CP and In4-Zr6 have almost equal indium-zirconium molar ratios. Fig. S2 exhibits that the In4Zr6Ox-CP and In4-Zr6-PM possess a type IV adsorption isotherm with hysteresis loops. And the BET surface area of In4Zr6Ox-CP is 86.89 m2/g (Table 3), slightly higher than that of In4-Zr6 mixed oxides, while In4-Zr6-PM has a low BET surface area. All of these results exclude the possibility of performance differences due to textural properties of In4-Zr6 and In4Zr6Ox-CP, whereas In-Zr interactions may be weak in In4-Zr6-PM. For H2-TPR of In4Zr6Ox-CP (Fig. S3a), the main reduction peak at high temperature, which is assigned to the reduction of bulk In2O3 into metallic indium, is shifted toward higher temperature compared to that of In4-Zr6 oxide, indicating that the formation of the In-Zr solid solution makes the In species harder to be reduced. For In4-Zr6-PM (Fig. S3a), the peak belongs to the reduction of In2O3, since zirconium oxide is not reduced at the test temperature. The CO2-TPD patterns (Fig. S3b) reveal that In4-Zr6 oxide and In4Zr6Ox-CP have almost the same CO2 adsorption capacity. The total amount of adsorbed CO2 is 2.18 m m o l · g − 1 , which is slightly less than that of In4-Zr6 mixed oxides. For In4-Zr6-PM, the desorption peak almost coincides with that of ZrO2, and the adsorption capacity for CO2 is weak at the reaction temperature. XPS spectrum was employed to reveal the surface composition and structure differences among In4-Zr6 oxides catalyst, In4Zr6Ox-CP and In4-Zr6-PM. For In 3d and Zr 3d (Fig. S4a, b), the binding energy of In4Zr6Ox-CP is higher than that of In4-Zr6. In contrast, the binding energies of In and Zr in In4-Zr6-PM are barely shifted, indicating that there may be no interaction. As displayed in Fig. S4c and Table S1, the concentrations of the surface oxygen vacancies of In4Zr6Ox-CP are significantly lower than that of In4-Zr6 mixed oxides. It is reported that the In-VO-Zr and In-VO-In are considered as active sites for indium-zirconium solid solution catalysts and indium oxide catalysts, respectively [16,22,24]. Both In-VO-Zr and In-VO-In active sites may co-exist and act synergistically in the In4-Zr6 oxide catalyst, which leads to higher content of oxygen vacancies and facilitate the CO2 hydrogenation more than a single In-VO-Zr or In-VO-In active site, and low content of oxygen vacancies is one of the reasons for the lower performance of In4Zr6Ox-CP. To find out the differences after CO2 hydrogenation, XPS of used samples was carried out. After the reaction, the binding energy of In 3d (Fig. 10a ) became lower, and the generation of metallic In can be observed, which may be produced by the partial reduction of In2O3. On the contrary, the binding energy of Zr 3d (Fig. 10b) shifted to a higher value, indicating that the electron transfer from t-ZrO2 to c-In2O3 [23]. This phenomenon was observed in both In4-Zr6 mixed oxide and In4Zr6Ox-CP samples (Fig. 10c, d), and there was no shift in the used In4-Zr6-PM (Fig. S5). However, it is obvious that the intensity of the In4-Zr6 shift is greater than the variation of In4Zr6Ox-CP, which indicates that the electron transfer is stronger in In4-Zr6 during the reaction. The same results have also been observed by Yang et al. and they concluded that electron transfer between In and Zr plays an important role in the methanol synthesis [23]. More importantly, the surface In/Zr atomic ratios increase from 0.33 to 0.38 for In4-Zr6 oxide while decrease from 0.42 to 0.39 for In4Zr6Ox-CP after the catalysis evaluation (Table S2). The increase of In/Zr atomic ratio in In4-Zr6 oxide may be caused by the reduction of In species to In0, while the decrease of In4Zr6Ox-CP may be caused by the further dissolution of In species to Zr species. However, the oxygen vacancies are increase for both of the two catalysts, the former increase by 4% and the latter increase by 12% after the catalyst test (Table S1). This indicates that oxygen vacancies are mainly generated by In-VO-In sites in In2O3 for In4-Zr6 oxide and by In-VO-Zr sites for In4Zr6Ox-CP during the CO2 hydrogenation. Fig. 11 illustrates the key differences between different catalysts synthesized by various preparation methods. In brief, we compared In4Zr6Ox-CP, In4-Zr6-PM, and In4-Zr6 mixed oxides, and found that forming zirconium-based solid solution did not exhibit excellent catalytic properties, even worse than those of pure indium oxide. The In4-Zr6 mixed oxides prepared by hydrothermal method were more easily reduced than In4Zr6Ox-CP and possessed a higher concentration of surface oxygen vacancies and stronger electron transfer, which may due to the synergistic effects by In-VO-Zr and In-VO-In. By comparing the characterization of In4-Zr6-PM, it can be concluded that In and Zr species are not simply mixed in In4-Zr6 mixed oxides, but forming a strong interaction. For In8-Zr2 and In6-Zr4, In2O3 in both samples was present in the form of large flakes of oxide. For In4-Zr6, the addition of the appropriate amount of zirconium resulted in smaller and more uniform nanoparticles of In2O3 with increased BET surface area and higher concentration of surface oxygen vacancies, thus In4-Zr6 possessing better catalytic performance in the CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. 4 Conclusion In conclusion, the Inx-Zry mixed oxides catalysts exhibited a promoted catalytic performance for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. The catalyst evaluation results confirm that the incorporation of ZrO2 enhanced the methanol selectivity significantly. Especially In4-Zr6 catalyst, which presents a mixed oxide composition, exhibits the highest methanol space-time yield, with a methanol selectivity of 77.34% and a CO2 conversion of 8.83% under 300 °C and 3 Mpa. The structural effects due to the addition of ZrO2 are proved by the XRD patterns, N2 adsorption-desorption results, and HRTEM images. Both the reduced grain size and the increased BET surface area facilitate the activation and hydrogenation of CO2. The CO2-TPD profiles show an enhanced basic strength of Inx-Zry mixed oxides catalysts, which leads to higher CO2 adsorption strength and capacity. The XPS profiles demonstrate that the addition of zirconium can increase the content of surface oxygen vacancies. Furthermore, the mixed metal oxide catalysts also exhibited higher oxygen vacancies concentration and stronger electron transfer than In-Zr solid solution catalysts. All these enhancements from the effect of the structural and mixed oxide make this catalyst a more promising catalyst than indium oxide, and this Inx-Zry mixed oxides catalysts have enormous potential to catalyze CH3OH synthesis in industry. coredata.dc:description: In2O3-based catalysts are considered to be promising catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol, while ZrO2 exhibits a significant improvement of the catalytic activity of In2O3 catalysts. In this work, Inx-Zry mixed oxides catalysts were prepared by a hydrothermal method and tested for methanol synthesis from CO2 hydrogenation at 260–320 °C and 2–5 Mpa. The results showed that all Inx-Zry mixed oxides catalysts show superior catalytic performances than pure In2O3 due to the contribution of oxygen vacancies and the activation of CO2 by zirconia. Further investigation showed that the catalytic performance of Inx-Zry mixed oxide with the coexistence of In-VO-In and In-VO-Zr sites is better than that of In4Zr6Ox-CP solid solution which only possesses single In-VO-Zr sites, due to the higher oxygen vacancy content and stronger electronic interactions between In and Zr species.
coredata.dc:title: CO2 hydrogenation to methanol over hydrothermally synthesized Inx-Zry catalysts
